{{Spanish name|Enríquez|Cabot}} [[File:Juan Enríquez - PopTech 2012.jpg|thumb|Portrait of Juan Enríquez Cabot at PopTech 2012]] '''Juan Enríquez Cabot''' (born 1959)<ref>{{cite web |url=http://id.loc.gov/authorities/names/n2001099240.html |title=Enriquez, Juan, 1959- |publisher=U.S. Library of Congress |accessdate=January 25, 2015 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150509001417/http://id.loc.gov/authorities/names/n2001099240.html |archivedate=9 May 2015 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> is a Mexican-American academic, businessman, author, and speaker.<ref>Javier Solana Hombre Despierto, Hombre Dormido 2011 – Page 418 "Un científico mexicano ilustre, tan ilustre como desconocido, y de excepcional inteligencia, es Juan Enríquez, a quien conocen más en el mundo que aquí en su tierra. Estos son algunos de sus pensamientos:</ref> He is currently the Managing Director of Excel Venture Management.
==Biography== Enríquez is the son of Antonio Enríquez Savignac<ref>[[Antonio Enr%C3%ADquez Savignac]]</ref>{{Better source|reason=per WP:CIRCULAR|date=June 2018}} and [[Marjorie Cabot Lewis]] of the Boston [[Cabot family]].<ref>{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=HzliP-e4qnUC&pg=PA217|page=217|title=Mexican Political Biographies, 1935–1993|author=Roderic Ai Camp|publisher=University of Texas Press|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180301135254/https://books.google.com/books?id=HzliP-e4qnUC&pg=PA217|archivedate=1 March 2018|df=dmy-all|isbn=9780292783621}}</ref> He is a graduate of [[Phillips Academy Andover]] (1977) and [[Harvard]], where he earned a B.A. (1981)<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1986/09/14/style/mary-schneider-weds-classmate.html|title=Mary Schneider Weds Classmate|date=September 14, 1986|quote=Mary Schneider and Juan Enriquez-Cabot, who graduated cum laude and magna cum laude, respectively, with the class of '81 from Harvard College|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160307031610/http://www.nytimes.com/1986/09/14/style/mary-schneider-weds-classmate.html|archivedate=7 March 2016|df=dmy-all}}</ref> and an MBA (1986), with honors.
==Academic research== The Founding Director of the Life Sciences Project at [[Harvard Business School]] (HBS), Enríquez is also a fellow of Harvard's [[Center for International Affairs]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ted.com/speakers/juan_enriquez.html|title=Juan Enriquez Profile on TED.com|accessdate=6 June 2012|work=[[TED (conference)|TED]]|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120604140438/http://www.ted.com/speakers/juan_enriquez.html|archivedate=4 June 2012|df=dmy-all}}</ref> His work has been published in the ''[[Harvard Business Review]]'', ''[[Foreign Policy]]'', ''Science'', and ''[[The New York Times]]''. He is the author of many books, including ''Evolving Ourselves: How Unnatural Selection and Nonrandom Mutation are Changing Life on Earth'' (Current-Penguin Group, 2015), ''Homo Evolutis: Please Meet the Next Human Species'' (TED, 2012), ''As the Future Catches You: How Genomics & Other Forces are Changing Your Life, Work, Health & Wealth'' (Crown Business, 2005), and ''The United States of America: Polarization, Fracturing, and Our Future'' (Random House, 2005). He works in business, science, and domestic/international politics.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.tedmed.com/speakers/show?id=6495|title=Juan Enriquez|website=TEDMED|access-date=2017-10-09|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170729202121/http://tedmed.com/speakers/show?id=6495|archivedate=29 July 2017|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
Enríquez is recognized as a leading authority on the economic and political impacts of the [[List of life sciences|life sciences]]. He is currently chairman and CEO of Biotechonomy LLC, a life sciences research and investment firm.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2010-07-07/juan-enriquez-discusses-advances-in-synthetic-biology-video.html|title=Juan Enriquez Discusses Advances in Synthetic Biology|date=7 July 2010|work=[[Bloomberg L.P.]]|accessdate=11 August 2010|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110402073343/http://www.bloomberg.com/news/2010-07-07/juan-enriquez-discusses-advances-in-synthetic-biology-video.html|archivedate=2 April 2011|df=dmy-all}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/research/stocks/private/person.asp?personId=8074080&privcapId=25238113|title=Juan Enriquez: Executive Profile & Biography - Bloomberg|website=www.bloomberg.com|access-date=2017-10-09|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180301135254/https://www.bloomberg.com/research/stocks/private/person.asp?personId=8074080&privcapId=25238113|archivedate=1 March 2018|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
He has written several articles, including "Transforming Life, Transforming Business: the Life Science Revolution," which was co-authored with Ray Goldberg and which received a [[McKinsey Prize]] in 2000 (2nd place). Enríquez also co-authored the first map of global [[nucleotide]] data flow, as well as HBS's working papers on "Life Sciences in Arabic Speaking Countries," "Global Life Science Data Flows and the IT industry," "[[Severe acute respiratory syndrome|SARS]], [[Smallpox]], and Business Unusual," and "Technology, Gene Research and National Competitiveness." ''Harvard Business School Interactive'' picked Enríquez as one of the best teachers at the school, and showcased his work in its first set of faculty products.
The ''[[Harvard Business Review]]'' showcased his ideas as one of the breakthrough concepts in its first HBR List. ''[[Fortune (magazine)|Fortune]]'' profiled him as "Mr. Gene." The [[Van Heyst Group]] asked him to co-organize the life sciences summit commemorating the fiftieth anniversary of the discovery of [[DNA]]. The summit "The Future of Life" was sponsored by ''[[Time (magazine)|Time]]''. ''[[Seed (magazine)|Seed]]'' picked his ideas as one of fifty that "shaped our identity, our culture, and the world as we know it".
==Business ventures== Enríquez serves on a variety of boards including: [[Cabot Corporation]], Zipongo, ShapeUp, [[Synthetic Genomics]], the [[Harvard Medical School]] Genetics Advisory Council, the Chairman's International Council of the [[Americas Society]], the Visiting Committee of Harvard's [[David Rockefeller Center for Latin American Studies|David Rockefeller Center]], [[Tufts University]]'s [[EPIIC]], TED's Brain Trust, Harvard Business School's PAPSAC, [[WGBH Educational Foundation|WGBH]], and the [[Museum of Science (Boston)]].
Enríquez joined a multi-stage world sailing discovery voyage led by [[J. Craig Venter]], who sequenced the [[human genome]]. The expedition voyage sampled microbial [[genome]]s throughout the world's oceans. This expedition involved a number of institutions and top scholars including [[The Institute for Genomic Research]], [[Woods Hole Oceanographic Institution]], The [[Explorers Club]], and Prof. [[E. O. Wilson]]. It also led to the discovery of an unprecedented number of new species.
Enríquez served as CEO of [[Mexico City|Mexico]] City's Urban Development Corporation, coordinator general of economic policy and chief of staff for Mexico's secretary of state, and as a member of the peace commission that negotiated the cease-fire in [[Chiapas]]' [[Zapatista Army of National Liberation|Zapatista]] rebellion.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ted.com/speakers/juan_enriquez.html|title=Juan Enriquez Profile on TED.com|accessdate=6 June 2012|work=[[TED (conference)|TED]]|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120604140438/http://www.ted.com/speakers/juan_enriquez.html|archivedate=4 June 2012|df=dmy-all}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.biotechonomy.com/juan.htm|title=Juan Enriquez Bio on Biotechonomy|accessdate=6 June 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120620183202/http://www.biotechonomy.com/juan.htm|archivedate=20 June 2012|df=dmy-all}}</ref>

(TEDxSummit 2012)] ** [http://www.ted.com/talks/juan_enriquez_how_to_think_about_digital_tattoos Juan Enriquez: Your online life, permanent as a tattoo (TED2013)]

{{Infobox politician | name = Salmeen, Khaled | image = | birth_date = {{birth year and age|1974}} | birth_place = [[Abu Dhabi]], [[United Arab Emirates]] | occupation = Chairman, [[Abu Dhabi Terminals]] (ADT), senior strategic and commercial advisor to the board of [[Abu Dhabi Ports Company]] | alma_mater = [[Colorado School of Mines]] }} '''Khaled Salmeen''' (Arabic: خالد سالمين) (born 1974) is chairman of [[Abu Dhabi Terminals]] (ADT), and a leading advisor to [[Abu Dhabi Ports]] in the [[emirate of Abu Dhabi]].<ref>{{cite news|author= |url=http://www.thebusinessyear.com/vip_interview/2545/khaled-salmeen-al-kawari|title=VIP INTERVIEW: Khaled Salmeen Al Kawari|publisher=The Business Year|date=November 2013 |accessdate=2014-02-19}}</ref> An [[Emiratis|Emirati]] national, Salmeen has spearheaded and led a number of major infrastructure projects in the emirate. For five years, in the role of CEO and managing director of [[Khalifa Industrial Zone Abu Dhabi]] ([[Kizad]]), Salmeen played a central role in helping to develop the emirate's industrial and manufacturing economy<ref>{{cite news|author= |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=hH1IQf5Gnnw|title=Abu Dhabi Quality Forum Khaled Salmeen Al Kawari|publisher=Abu Dhabi Quality Forum on YouTube|date=2013-05-16}}</ref> - one of the main goals set out by the Abu Dhabi government's Abu Dhabi Economic Vision 2030 to diversify the local economy away from oil and gas.<ref>{{cite news|author= |url=http://www.oxfordbusinessgroup.com/news/major-player-obg-talks-khaled-salmeen-ceo-and-managing-director-kizad|title=Major player: OBG talks to Khaled Salmeen, CEO and Managing Director, Kizad|publisher=Oxford Business Group|date=June 2013 |accessdate=2014-02-19}}</ref>
Before taking up his position at Kizad in 2009, Salmeen project managed the development of [[Masdar]]'s hydrogen power plant as well as specializing in carbon capture and storage before going on to serve two years as chief operation officer at [[Abu Dhabi]]'s leading district cooling company, Tabreed, from 2007.<ref>{{cite news|author= |url=http://www.constructionweekonline.com/article-6610-tabreed-chief-quits/|title=Tabreed chief quits|publisher=Construction Week|date=2009-10-11 |accessdate=2014-02-19}}</ref>
== Education == Salmeen holds a B.Sc. in Engineering from [[Colorado School of Mines]] in the United States and a [[Project Management Professional]] (PMP) from the [[Project Management Institute]] (PMI) and [[Harvard Business School]].<ref>{{cite news|author= |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=HKm2QsXPkBk|title=France 24 (Arabic) sits down with Kizad's CEO Khaled Salmeen |publisher=France 24 Arabic}}</ref>

{{More citations needed|date=February 2013}} [[PepsiCo]] has produced a number of variations on its primary [[cola]], [[Pepsi]], over the years, including the following:
==Sodas== {{Repetition|date=August 2008}} *'''[[Pepsi]]''': [[PepsiCo]]'s signature cola flavor and its namesake cola. *'''[[Caffeine-Free Pepsi|Pepsi Free]]''': Introduced in 1982 by PepsiCo as the first major-brand caffeine-free cola and is today sold as [[Caffeine-Free Pepsi]] and [[Caffeine-Free Pepsi|Caffeine-Free Diet Pepsi]]. *'''[[Pepsi Wild Cherry]]''': Introduced in 1988, it is cherry flavored cola. Known as Wild Cherry Pepsi until 2005. It was named Wild Cherry to not be confused with Coke's Cherry variation. Available nationally in the [[United States]], [[Canada]] and [[Russia]]. *'''[[Crystal Pepsi]]''': the Clear version of cola; introduced in 1992 and sold until 1993, it returned in 2015 as part of a limited sweepstakes promotion, and has been re-released several times since. **'''Crystal from Pepsi''': Discontinued citrus/cola hybrid; reformulation of Crystal Pepsi<ref>{{cite web|url=http://adage.com/article/news/pepsi-sees-citrus-appeal-crystal/90890/|title=PEPSI SEES CITRUS APPEAL IN ITS CRYSTAL|publisher=}}</ref> **'''Pepsi Clear''': Clear Pepsi released in Mexico as a limited edition during Christmas 2005, the Mexican equivalent of Crystal Pepsi. *'''Pepsi AM''': Contains more [[caffeine]] than a regular Pepsi and marketed as a morning drink. Sold in Germany in 2008. *'''Diet Pepsi Lemon''': A new flavor of Diet Pepsi released in 2009. *'''Diet Pepsi Lime''': A lime-flavored diet Pepsi. Temporarily available. *'''Pepsi Twist Zero''': Available in Brazil *'''[[Diet Pepsi Max]]''': Was available in the United States and Canada. Diet Pepsi with added caffeine and ginseng. This product is not related to Pepsi Max as it has significantly different ingredients and no calories.<ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.bevnet.com/news/2007/02-22-2007-pepsi_max.asp |website= BevNET.com |location= Purchase, New York |title= New Invigorating Zero-Calorie Cola Hits Shelves This Summer |date= February 22, 2007 |accessdate= January 10, 2016}}</ref> Diet Pepsi Max was renamed "Pepsi Max" in late 2008 along with the redesign of Pepsi. *'''[[Pepsi Max]]''': Was only available outside the [[United States]] until the name change of Diet Pepsi Max in 2008. Pepsi with no sugar. **'''Pepsi Max Cool Lemon''': Pepsi Max with lemon available in Belgium in 2006. **'''Pepsi Max Chill''': (flavored with apple) **'''Pepsi Max Mojo''': A variation flavoured with lime and a hint of mint. Sold in Finland in 2008. **'''Pepsi Max Citron Citron Vert''' (sold in France) **'''Pepsi Max Cino''': (UK - Pepsi Max with coffee) Discontinued<ref>{{cite web|author=mcjakeqcool |url=http://www.marketingweek.co.uk/news/supermarkets-poised-to-axe-pepsi-coffee-flavoured-cola/2053225.article |title=Supermarkets poised to axe Pepsi coffee-flavoured cola |publisher=Marketing Week |date= |accessdate=2010-06-01}}</ref> **'''Pepsi Max Energy''': Pepsi Max with 66% more caffeine, flavored with ginseng. Sold in Germany in 2008. **'''Pepsi Max Gold''': Limited edition in the UK market for Christmas 2005; available September to December **'''Pepsi Max Twist''': Lemon and lime flavor available in the UK **'''Pepsi Max Mojito''': [[Mojito]] flavor available in [[Denmark]] **'''Pepsi Max Cease Fire''': With a hint of lime. It is meant to be consumed with [[Doritos]] burn, to "cool the burn". Sold in the United States, Australia, and New Zealand. In the UK, it is called Citrus Freeze. **'''Pepsi Max Punch''': A low calorie edition of Pepsi Holiday Spice. Only sold in the UK in Christmas 2005. **'''Pepsi Max Cherry''': A cherry-flavoured Pepsi Max. Released in the UK in June 2011 only at Asda stores in 2 liter bottles, as of 2012 available in other select retail stores. Also available in France as of 2014, in Denmark, Norway, and Germany as of 2015 and in Finland and Iceland as of 2016. Available in Russia since late 2017 or early 2018.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.rayon-boissons.com/Nouveaux-Produits/Pepsi-Max-a-son-cherry-29039 |language= French |title= Pepsi Max a son cherry |trans-title= Pepsi Max has cherry |date= April 1, 2014 |publisher=Rayon Bouissons |accessdate= January 10, 2016}}</ref> **'''Pepsi Max Citrus Freeze''': A lime-flavoured Pepsi Max similar to Cease Fire. Released in the UK in October 2011 for a limited time. **'''Pepsi Max Vanilla''': A vanilla-flavoured Pepsi max available in Australia since February 2018 and in New Zealand since April 2018. **'''Pepsi Max Lime''': A lime-flavoured Pepsi max available in Denmark since January 2018, in Sweden since March 2018, in Russia and in Finland. It was available in Australia for a limited run in 2016. **'''Pepsi Max Ginger''': A Ginger-flavoured Pepsi max available in the united kingdom and since 2017 in Norway, Finland, The Netherlands, Denmark and Sweden. *'''Pepsi Max Wild Side''': "Wild baobab flavor, no sugar" flavor sold in Sweden in 2010. *'''Pepsi NEX''': A zero-calorie Pepsi available in Japan and South Korea, developed by [[Suntory]]<ref>{{cite press release |url= http://www.suntory.com/about/news/2006/9340.html|title=Suntory Announces Launch of "PEPSI NEX" ~ World Debut of Original Suntory PEPSI Brand ~ New Generation Cola Hits Store Shelves Refuting the idea that 'colas come from America' |website= Suntory.com |date= 19 January 2006 |accessdate= 2006-07-04}}</ref> (Also advertised through the anime ''[[Tiger & Bunny]]'' and ''[[U-Know]]'' and ''[[Changmin|Max]]'' of [[TVXQ]])<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=7sD5ejwPeGA|title=Tiger & Bunny - Blue Rose's Commercial : Pepsi NEX |website= YouTube}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://sportsworldi.segye.com/Articles/EntCulture/Article.asp?aid=20110512002791&subctg1=50&subctg2=00 |title=동방신기, '펩시 넥스' CF모델 선정 - 건강한 웃음 푸른 희망 - 스포츠월드 |trans-title= TVXQ, 'Pepsi Nex' CF model chosen |publisher=Sportsworldi.segye.com |language= Korean |date= May 12, 2011 |accessdate=2012-09-26}}</ref> *'''[[Pepsi Next]]''': a mid-calorie version of Pepsi released in March 2012, described by the company as having "60% lower sugar content and fewer calories."<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/greatspeculations/2012/04/09/pepsico-bubbles-to-71-by-boosting-soft-drink-sales/ |work=[[Forbes]] |title= PepsiCo Bubbles To $71 By Pumping Up Pepsi Next |first= Trefis |last= Team |date= April 9, 2012 |accessdate= January 10, 2016}}</ref> **'''Pepsi Next Cherry Vanilla'''<ref name=Marvo730>{{cite news |url=http://www.theimpulsivebuy.com/wordpress/2012/07/30/review-pepsi-next-cherry-vanilla-pepsi-next-paradise-mango/ |title= REVIEW: Pepsi Next Cherry Vanilla & Pepsi Next Paradise Mango |author= Marvo |website= TheImpulsiveBuy.com |date= July 30, 2012 |accessdate= January 10, 2016 }}</ref> **'''Pepsi Next Paradise Mango'''<ref name=Marvo730 /> *'''[[Pepsi ONE]]''': An alternative to Diet Pepsi, with one calorie per serving. It continued to use the 2003 Pepsi design until mid-2012. *'''[[Pepsi Twist|Diet Pepsi Twist]]''' **'''Diet Pepsi Kickoff''': Diet Pepsi with Lemon. To be released for the 2008 [[NFL]] season. **'''Diet Pepsi Twistão''' (see above) *'''Diet Pepsi Vanilla''': Vanilla-flavored diet soda. Pepsi's response to Diet Vanilla Coke. Temporarily available. *'''Diet Pepsi Wild Cherry''': Not widely available until 2005, when Wild Cherry Pepsi was reformulated. Now uses the 2008 Pepsi design *'''Pepsi XL''' another mid-calorie cola targeted at males, and transition consumers (those making the move from regular to diet colas). *'''Pepsi Sugar Free''': Released in November 2007. *'''Pepsi Twist 3''': Released in Brazil in 2008. It has 3 calories of the natural lemon juice. *'''[[Pepsi Zero Sugar|Pepsi Black]]''': Introduced in 2017 in Croatia, the Czech Republic, Greece, Hungary, Slovakia, Slovenia, and Ukraine. Similar but not to be confused with Pepsi Max. In Croatia, Greece, Hungary, Slovenia, and Ukraine it replaced the locally unsuccessful Pepsi Light.<ref>[http://pepsisi.lin54.host25.com/pepsi-black.html Pepsi brez sladkorjev] - Official Pepsi Slovenia - Pepsi Black</ref> *'''Diet Pepsi with Splenda''': Diet Pepsi sweetened with [[Splenda]]. First released in 2015 as a reformulation of regular Diet Pepsi, which replaced the original aspartame-sweetened formula until 2018. While no longer available for retail, it can still be purchased via [[E-commerce]].<ref>[http://www.pepsicobeveragefacts.com/Home/product?formula=F0000003519&form=RTD&size=12 Diet Pepsi with Splenda] - Official Site for PepsiCo Beverage Information | Product</ref>
==Fictional drinks== *'''Pepsi Perfect''': A vitamin-enriched Pepsi variation shown in the movie ''[[Back to the Future Part II]]'' in scenes set in the year 2015.

{{BLP sources|date=January 2018}} '''Mariusz Świtalski''' (born May 19, 1962) is a [[Poles|Polish]] entrepreneur. He is the founder of [[Elektromis]], [[Eurocash]], [[Biedronka]], [[Żabka (convenience store)|Żabka]], [[Małpka Express]] and has been named as one of the richest people in Poland by [[Wprost|Wprost weekly]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.money.pl/gospodarka/wiadomosci/artykul/czerwona-torebka-mariusz-switalski-maszyny,6,0,2325254.html|title=Czerwona Torebka wraca do gry. Wydała 300 mln zł na maszyny górnicze|last=Frączyk|first=Jacek|date=2017-05-25|work=WP money|access-date=2018-01-25|language=pl-PL}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://poznan.wyborcza.pl/poznan/7,36001,22744798,piotr-najsztub-zeznaje-w-sprawie-zabojstwa-dziennikarza-mariusz.html|title=Piotr Najsztub zeznaje w sprawie zabójstwa dziennikarza: Mariusz Świtalski groził mi z łagodnym uśmiechem|work=poznan.wyborcza.pl|access-date=2018-01-25|language=pl-PL}}</ref>
== Biography and Career == He grew up in various orphanages, the longest in a house run by nuns in [[Szamotuły]]. He graduated from a 2-year vocational school in plumbing.
In the 80s he traded at the [[Poznań]] trade fair, at the end of the 1980s he specialized in coffee making and then in computer hardware distribution.
In 1987, he founded [[Elektromis]], an enterprise importing [[confectionery]], radio and television equipment, beer and spirits. Within 2 years, it transformed into a huge holding. Some of his companies back then were registered and ran by his friends from the orphanages. In 1992, [[Elektromis]] owned 50 warehouses throughout [[Poland]] and PLN 168 million of profit per year.
In 1993, he transformed Elektromis into [[Eurocash]], which became the largest grocery wholesale chain in [[Poland]]. In 1995 he sold it to [[Jerónimo Martins]]. In 1995, he founded the discount chain [[Biedronka]], which he sold (243 branches) in 1998 also to [[Jerónimo Martins]].
He was the owner of the weekly ''Miliarder''. He helped [[Jerzy Urban]] in setting up the weekly "''Nie''". He founded the Posnania bank, which, however, in 1995 closed down.
In 1998, he founded [[Żabka (convenience store)|Żabka]], whose shares in 2000 were bought by the AIG fund.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.thenews.pl/1/12/Artykul/307770,EBRD-to-invest-in-Polandbased-grocery-retailer-Zabka|title=EBRD to invest in Poland-based grocery retailer Żabka|work=Polskie Radio dla Zagranicy|access-date=2018-01-25}}</ref>
In 2011, he launched the "Sowiniec FIZ" fund investing in real estate. It owns land between [[Puszczykowo]] near [[Poznań]] and [[Sowiniec, West Pomeranian Voivodeship|Sowiniec]]. At the end of the 1990s, he also bought plots in Poznań, in the [[Stare Miasto, Poznań|Naramowice]] housing estate.
In December 2010, the Poznań-based company [[Świtalski & Synowie]] changed its name to Czerwona Torebka SA. In 2013, he created the discount chain store Czerwony Torebka. In April 2015, the management of the company Dyskont Czerwona Torebka SA decided to liquidate the company. In July of the same year, all stores were closed, and the company Czerwona Naporeka ceased to exist.
As of 2015, he was the 40th richest person in Poland as named by [[Wprost]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://rankingi.wprost.pl/100-najbogatszych-polakow/2015|title=100 Najbogatszych Polaków 2015|website=Rankingi Wprost|language=pl|access-date=2018-01-25}}</ref>

{{Infobox company | name = McGill Executive Institute | logo = MEI logo.tiff | logo_size = 260px | type = Not for Profit | foundation = [[Montreal]], [[Quebec]], Canada ({{Start date|1956}}) | location_city = Montreal, Quebec | location_country = [[Canada]] | area_served = Worldwide | key_people = Professor Louis Gialloreto, Executive Director | industry = [[Executive Education]] | products = Management Seminars, Custom Business Solutions | owner = [[McGill University]] | num_employees = | parent = [[Desautels Faculty of Management]] | homepage = [http://www.executive.mcgill.ca/ www.executive.mcgill.ca] }} The '''McGill Executive Institute''' is the corporate education and management development unit of the [[McGill University]] [[Desautels Faculty of Management]] in [[Montreal|Montreal, Quebec]], Canada. It provides a variety of public business seminars as well as custom [[executive education]] and coaching for all levels of management. Founded in 1956,[https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=QokxAAAAIBAJ&sjid=naUFAAAAIBAJ&dq=mcgill%20executive-development&pg=1308%2C2644596 McGill Management Institute teaches the unusual...it’s where executives go to learn about computers], The Montreal Gazette, Aug 18, 1984, Retrieved on August 7, 2010 the Institute has a full-time staff of learning design and program managers working with professors at McGill’s Faculties of Management, Law, Arts, Education and Medicine, external guest experts in specific fields, as well as visiting professors from universities worldwide. The Institute’s clientele includes businesses, not-for-profit organizations and government/public sector services. ==History== After establishing the first management diploma in 1906, McGill University began offering evening classes in business education in 1912.[https://www.mcgill.ca/study/2010-2011/sites/mcgill.ca.study.2010-2011/files/desautels_faculty_of_management_201011_0.pdf Desautels Faculty of Management: Programs, Courses and University Regulations 2010-2011], Desautels Website, PDF retrieved on August 9, 2010 Following Canada's post World War II expansion, McGill University responded to the needs of senior executives by offering seminars in personnel management, marketing, and finance.[https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=EIMtAAAAIBAJ&sjid=dpkFAAAAIBAJ&dq=mcgill%20personnel-management&pg=3548%2C915652 McGill University Evening Extension Course listing], The Montreal Gazette - Sep 8, 1950, Retrieved on August 9, 2010 Concurrent to business seminars offered by McGill, the Executive Development Institute, a private business education organization, began to offer the Executive Development Course (EDC) in 1949, in affiliation with the [[Montreal Board of Trade]]. It was developed with support from the Graduate School of Business at [[Harvard University]].[https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=vJgtAAAAIBAJ&sjid=kZ0FAAAAIBAJ&dq=executive-development-institute%20board-of-trade&pg=3255%2C552133 Executive Development Institute, 12th Annual EDC], The Montreal Gazette - Sep 5, 1961, Retrieved on August 11, 2010[https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=aMItAAAAIBAJ&sjid=d54FAAAAIBAJ&dq=montreal%20board-of-trade%20seminar%20institute%20executive&pg=4026%2C1105140 Executive Development Institute, 13th Annual EDC], The Montreal Gazette - Sep 7, 1962, Retrieved on August 11, 2010[https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=W8MtAAAAIBAJ&sjid=_Z4FAAAAIBAJ&dq=executive-development-institute%20board-of-trade&pg=1953%2C316811 Executive Development Institute, 15th Annual EDC], The Montreal Gazette - Aug 3, 1964, Retrieved on August 11, 2010 A precursor to the existence of many MBA and later EMBA programs, the EDC was designed to provide a comprehensive look at management practices in strategy, human resources, marketing, negotiations and financial acumen.[https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=kZMtAAAAIBAJ&sjid=j54FAAAAIBAJ&dq=executive-development-institute%20board-of-trade&pg=3272%2C1782776 To Help the Executive Grow], The Montreal Gazette - Jul 11, 1963, Retrieved on August 11, 2010 In 1956, the McGill Management Institute was founded to facilitate the more effective delivery of business seminars offered at McGill University. In 1973, the Executive Development Institute merged with the McGill Management Institute and, under the McGill banner, continued the facilitation of the EDC.[https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=UhQyAAAAIBAJ&sjid=3qEFAAAAIBAJ&dq=mcgill%20executive-development&pg=1486%2C4031929 Ross Plans Book on University Growth], The Montreal Gazette - Aug 31, 1973, Retrieved on August 7, 2010[https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=zYcxAAAAIBAJ&sjid=uKEFAAAAIBAJ&dq=mcgill%20executive-development&pg=5535%2C2565363 Psychological Survival for Executives], The Montreal Gazette - April 10, 1974, Retrieved on August 9, 2010 The merger coincided with a move to its current home in the Bronfman building at McGill University on Sherbrooke Street in Montreal, where it underwent a significant expansion of its offerings. By 1984, the McGill Management Institute was offering 70 day-time seminars and 20 evening courses each year, in addition to the EDC. In 1993, the McGill Management Institute was renamed the McGill International Executive Institute. It took its current name, the McGill Executive Institute, in 2002. It is a division of the [[Desautels Faculty of Management]]. ==Philosophy== The McGill Executive Institute has been noted for its approach to action-based learning,[https://dspace1.acs.ucalgary.ca/bitstream/1880/47681/1/Fowler_2009.pdf Executive Education in Canadian Firms] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110706210412/https://dspace1.acs.ucalgary.ca/bitstream/1880/47681/1/Fowler_2009.pdf |date=2011-07-06 }}, Bruce Gordon R. Fowler, University of Calgary, 2009, pg 213, Retrieved on September 9, 2010 as well as for its international dimension. In his 2009 work, ''Executive Education in Canadian Firms'', Bruce Gordon R. Fowler states the following:
The executive programs at this Institute recognize better than most schools, even among the other eight illustrious institutions discussed here, the need for international diversity and content. Indeed, McGill has been recognized as having an international dimension unsurpassed in North America for diversity among students and faculty, and for program style and content. The scope of McGill's global outlook is certainly equal to that of Harvard and INSEAD, also featured here as giants of international connectivity, which simply must be part of any program involving executives of international or multinational firms.[https://dspace1.acs.ucalgary.ca/bitstream/1880/47681/1/Fowler_2009.pdf Executive Education in Canadian Firms] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110706210412/https://dspace1.acs.ucalgary.ca/bitstream/1880/47681/1/Fowler_2009.pdf |date=2011-07-06 }}, Bruce Gordon R. Fowler, University of Calgary, 2009, pg 138, Retrieved on September 9, 2010
==Products and Services== Each year, the McGill Executive Institute provides approximately 20 to 40 open enrolment seminars addressing a number of business topics. The Institute’s longest running program is the Executive Development Course which was launched in 1949. The EDC has been expanded over the years, and is currently offered in three successive modules: the Executive Development Course, the Advanced Management Course, and Integrated Management Thinking. Together, these are referred to by the Institute as the [[Mini-MBA]] Series.[http://executive.mcgill.ca/seminars List of Seminars available from McGill Executive Institute website], Retrieved on September 9, 2010 The McGill Executive Institute also designs and delivers customized learning solutions specifically for an organization’s team of managers or executives. Services range from short workshops delivered in English, French or bilingual formats to global initiatives with delivery of modules to participants across management levels over several years. The McGill Executive Institute also offers an International Masters in Practicing Management (IMPM), as well as the Advanced Leadership Program (ALP). These longer, global programs occur over several modules and across multiple international locations, in conjunction with other universities: The Indian Institute of Management in Bangalore, India; Lancaster University in the UK; Korea Development Institute School of Public Policy and Management in Seoul, Korea; and INSEAD in France. Both the ALP and the IMPM were co-founded and are co-directed by Professor [[Henry Mintzberg]].[https://dspace1.acs.ucalgary.ca/bitstream/1880/47681/1/Fowler_2009.pdf Executive Education in Canadian Firms] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110706210412/https://dspace1.acs.ucalgary.ca/bitstream/1880/47681/1/Fowler_2009.pdf |date=2011-07-06 }}, Bruce Gordon R. Fowler, University of Calgary, 2009, pg 135, Retrieved on September 9, 2010 ==Faculty and Guest Speakers== Well-known McGill faculty members include Professor [[Henry Mintzberg]] on advanced leadership issues and Professor Nancy Adler on [[organizational behavior]]. Recent guest speakers of note have included business leaders [[Daniel Lamarre]], [[Larry Smith (Canadian football)|Larry Smith]], Jim Cherry, Alan Allnutt, Paul Côté and [[Pierre Boivin]]. ==Partners and Collaborators== The McGill Executive Institute partners with the [[Institute of Corporate Directors]] (ICD) in Canada to deliver the Director’s Education Program. It is also a registered education provider with the [[Project Management Institute]] (PMI) and collaborates with the Canadian Corporate Counsel Association to deliver development programs for lawyers on financial literacy. == References == {{Reflist}} ==External links== * [http://www.executive.mcgill.ca/ McGill Executive Institute] * [https://www.mcgill.ca/ McGill University] [[Category:McGill University]] [[Category:Business education]]

He was named Labor Minister on 22 November 2011 by [[Abdurrahim El-Keib]].{{cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2011/11/22/us-libya-idUSTRE7AL0JM20111122|agency=Reuters|date=22 November 2011|accessdate=23 November 2011|title=Libya's NTC unveils new government line-up}} Prior to the uprising that toppled the Gaddafi government of Libya, Mr. Rugibani was CEO of MTS{{clarify|date=January 2012}} in Libya {{cite web|title=E3 Conducts Seminar In Tripoli, Libya|url=http://www.e3corp.net/quality_healthcare_seminar_tripoli_2010.html|accessdate=29 November 2011|date=2 November 2010}} and chairman of United Business Machines, the authorized IBM Business Partner for the entire range of IBM products and services in Jordan.{{cite news|title=UBM.com answers Jordan's business needs for software solutions with new company launch|url=http://www.ameinfo.com/2835.html|accessdate=29 November 2011|newspaper=Ameinfo.com|date=30 January 2002}} ==External links== * [https://web.archive.org/web/20120103093318/http://eolibya.org/ Interim Government Official website (Executive Office)] * [http://www.libyanfsl.com/ National Front for the Salvation of Libya website] ==References== {{reflist}} {{National Transitional Council}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Rugibani, Mustafa}} [[Category:Government ministers of Libya]] [[Category:Libyan politicians]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Members of the National Transitional Council]] [[Category:Members of the Interim Government of Libya]] [[Category:Libyan businesspeople]] [[Category:Libyan Sunni Muslims]] {{Libya-bio-stub}}

{{notability|1=Biographies|date=November 2018}} {{Infobox person |name = Mustafa Vehbi Koç |image = MVK-2013.jpg |image_size = |caption = Mustafa Koç |birth_name = |birth_date = {{birth date|1960|10|29}} |birth_place = [[Ankara]], Turkey |death_date = {{death date and age|2016|01|21|1960|10|29}} |death_place = [[Istanbul]], Turkey |resting_place = [[Zincirlikuyu Cemetery]] |residence = |nationality = Turkish |ethnicity = |citizenship = |other_names = |known_for = Chairman of [[Koç Holding]] |education = |alma_mater = [[George Washington University]] |occupation = |years_active = |home_town = |salary = |networth = |title = |boards = |religion = |spouse = |children = 2 |parents = [[Rahmi Koç]] |relations = |website = }}
'''Mustafa Vehbi Koç''' (October 29, 1960 [[Ankara]] – January 21, 2016 [[Istanbul]]), also known as '''Mustafa Koç''', was a [[Turkish people|Turkish]] businessman and a third generation member of the [[Koç family]]. He is best known as the [[Chairman]] of [[Koç Holding]], a position he held from 2003 until his death in 2016.
==Private life== Mustafa Koç was born to [Rahmi Koç]], the second generation member of [[Koç family]] on October 29, 1960.<ref name="nyt1"/> He had two younger brothers [[Mehmet Ömer Koç]] (born 1962) and [[Ali Yıldırım Koç]] (born 1967).<ref name="nyt1"/> Graduating from [[Switzerland]]’s international boarding high school [[Lyceum Alpinum Zuoz]] in 1980, Mustafa Koç received his [[Bachelor's degree]] in [[Business Administration]] from [[George Washington University]] in 1984.<ref name="k"/><ref name="nyt1"/>
Koç was married to Caroline and was father of two daughters Esra and Aylin.<ref name="k"/><ref name="nyt1"/>
==Professional career== After graduation, Koç started working as a Consultant at [[Tofaş]]. Continuing his career as sales manager and later as assistant general manager for Sales at Ram Dış Ticaret, in 1992, he joined [[Koç Holding]] to serve as vice president.<ref name="k"/>
Working at Koç Holding, Turkey's largest industrial conglomerate and the only Turkish company listed in [[Fortune 500]],<ref name="hdn1"/><ref name="nyt1"/> for all of his career, Koç became a board member in 2001. Assuming the responsibility as vice chairman the following year, he took over the position of chairman from [[Rahmi Koç]], his retired father, in 2003.<ref name="hdn1"/><ref name="nyt1"/> Mustafa Koç was also the chairman for the High Advisory Council to [[TÜSİAD]], the Turkish Industry and Business Association, between 2003 until 2015.<ref name="k"/> Between 2006 and 2013, he held office as Honorary Consul for [[Finland]], as well as being a member of Council for Foreign Economic Affairs for the Istanbul Chamber of Industry. Koç also held various international positions during his career, including positions in [[JP Morgan]]’s International Council, [[Rolls Royce]] International’s Advisory Board, and [[Bilderberg Meetings]]’ Executive Board.<ref name="g1"/> He was awarded the Cavaliere D’Industria medal by the [[Italy|Italian]] government in 2005.<ref name="k"/>
==Death and Legacy== Mustafa Koç suffered from a [[heart attack]], and died after a heart attack during a fitness exercise at his home on January 21, 2016.<ref name="k"/><ref name="nyt1"/> He was buried at [[Zincirlikuyu Cemetery]] next to his grandfather's grave.<ref name="hdn1"/> A documentary film about the legacy of Mustafa Koç was produced in 2017. <ref>https://www.imdb.com/title/tt7791616/</ref>
He had been a life long [[sports]] enthusiast, with his hobbies ranging from [[sailing]] and [[golf]], to [[scuba diving]] and [[equestrianism|horseback riding]]. A sports award named after Mustafa Koç was established in 2017 to honor his memory. Celebrating the ideals and merits of sportsmanship, the "Mustafa V. Koç Sports Award" is judged by the [[Turkish Olympic Committee]].<ref name="hdn2"/>
==References== {{reflist|30em|refs= <ref name="k">{{cite web |url=https://www.koc.com.tr/en-us/about/mustafa-v-koc |publisher=Koç |title=Mustafa V. Businesswoman | religion = [[Buddhism]] |term_start = 12 February 2015 |term_end = | term_start2 = 4 January 2006 | term_end2 = 30 June 2016 }} '''Nualphan Lamsam''' ({{Lang-th|นวลพรรณ ล่ำซำ}}; {{Rtgs|''Nuanphan Lamsam''}}; born 21 March 1966), also known as '''Madame Pang''' after her nickname, is the President and Chief Executive Officer of [[Muang Thai Insurance]], as well as Chairwoman of [[Port Football Club]] and manager of the [[Thailand women's national football team]]. She is the daughter of Photipong Lamsam, Advisory Committee [[Democrat Party (Thailand)|Democrat Party,]] and Yupa Lamsam a major shareholder of Muang Thai Insurance Plc. Nualphan has a sister Wannaporn Phornprapa, the Managing Director of P Landscape Co. and a brother Sara Lamsam, the President & CEO of [[Muang Thai Life Assurance]] plc. She is the fifth generation descendant of [[Lamsam family]] and a cousin of [[Banthoon Lamsam]], the CEO and Chairman of [[Kasikornbank]].{{cite news|title=มาดามแป้ง นวลพรรณ ล่ำซํา ประวัติหญิงเก่ง เจ้าของฉายา สวยประหาร|url=http://hilight.kapook.com/view/102606|date=2014-10-12}} Nualphan graduated from [[Patumwan Demonstration School, Srinakharinwirot University]], Bachelor of Marketing, Faculty of Commerce and Accountancy, [[Chulalongkorn University]] and a Master of Management, [[Boston University]] USA.{{cite news|title=สุดโปรดของ 'นวลพรรณ ล่ำซำ'....นี่แหละ ! ขาดไม่ได้|url=http://www.manager.co.th/CelebOnline/ViewNews.aspx?NewsID=9530000097655|date=2010-09-19}} Nualphan first marriage was with Dr. Vachara Phanchet, Chairman of Sittipol Sales co. and German Auto co. They had one daughter, Nuanwan Phanchet. Nualphan and Dr. Vachara divorced in early 2005. Nualphan later married with the Pol. Col. Narat Sawettananas on 19 January 2014.{{cite news|title=สุดเซอร์ไพรส์ม่ายสาวไฮโซแป้ง-นวลพรรณ ย่องเงียบสละโสดรอบสอง|url=http://www.manager.co.th/celebonline/viewnews.aspx?NewsID=9570000007341|date=2014-01-20}} ==References== {{reflist}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Lamsam, Nualphan}} [[Category:1966 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Thai businesspeople]] [[Category:Lamsam family]]

'''Pay-to-fly or pay-to-work''' programs,<ref name=senat>{{cite web|last1=BOCQUET|first1=Éric|title=RAPPORT D´INFORMATION FAIT au nom de la commission des affaires européennes sur le dumping social dans les transports européens|url=http://www.senat.fr/rap/r13-450/r13-4501.pdf|publisher=Sénat (french Senate)|pages=41|language=French|issue=450|date=April 10, 2014}}</ref> sometimes referred to as "pay-to-fly"<ref name=usa-today>{{cite news|last1=Levin|first1=Alan|title=Airline that trained Buffalo crash pilot fined $1.3M|url=http://usatoday30.usatoday.com/news/washington/2009-05-21-buffalo-crash_N.htm|work=USA TODAY|date=May 21, 2009}}</ref> or "p2f", also known as 'self-sponsored line training',<ref name=pilotman>{{cite web|first1=Kevin|author1=Community Manager for Pilotman.net|title=What You Don’t Know About Line Training|url=http://www.pilotman.net/things-you-dont-know-line-training/}}</ref> are an aviation industry practice whereby a professional pilot operates an aircraft on revenue-earning commercial operation <ref name=biz>{{cite news|last1=Marques|first1=Charles|title=Cockpit Crews PAY TO FLY|url=http://aviationbm.e-publish.com/1d62c21e.C2RZH|work=Aviation Business Magazine|issue=January 2014}}</ref> by paying for it.<ref name=france-info>{{cite news|author1= Jérôme Jadot|title=Quand le copilote aussi paie sa place dans l’avion... (When the copilot also pays for his seat in the plane)|url=http://www.franceinfo.fr/emission/le-plus-france-info/2013-2014/quand-le-co-pilote-aussi-paie-sa-place-dans-l-avion-06-16-2014-18-30|work=France Info (radio)|date=June 17, 2014|language=French}}</ref>
Prices range from around 14,000 euros<ref name=ram>{{cite web|last1=CHAUVAC|first1=Pierre-Gabriel|title=AGREEMENT FOR LINE TRAINING PROGRAM WITH Royal Air Maroc Express|url=http://www.cockpitseeker.com/wp-content/uploads/goodies/p2f/RAMEX_Line_Trainee_Agreement.pdf|website=www.etops.net/|publisher=ETOPS flight Asia Limited|pages=8|year=2012}}</ref> to sometimes over 85,000 euros <ref name=france-2>{{cite news|last1=Poussery|first1=Lionel|title=Profession pilote : la fin du rêve? The new rules, which took effect in August, came in response to the 2009 crash of a Continental Express regional flight // ALPA President Lee Moak said [...] that aimed to refute the “myth” of such a shortage}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|author1=ALPA Staff|title=A Pilot Shortage?
