== Origin == On 2 November 1924, [[Harold Frederick Pitcairn|Harold Pitcairn]] founded the [[Eastern Airlines|Pitcairn Flying School and Passenger Service]].
Rebranded [[Eastern Air Lines]] in 1926, it flourished for decades after the 1950s until acquired by [[Frank Lorenzo|Franz Lorenzo]] in 1985 amidst indebtment and labour dispute in the new [[Airline Deregulation Act]] market. Management decisions (e.g. asset transfer to [[Continental Airlines]]) combined with further labour unrest against [[International Association of Machinists and Aerospace Workers|IAM]], [[Trans World Airlines|TWA]] and [[Air Line Pilots Association, International|ALPA]] during the [[List of strikes|1989 Easter Airline strike]] led to the company liquidation in 1991.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Grounded: Frank Lorenzo and the Destruction of Eastern Air Lines.|last=Bernstein|first=Aaron|publisher=Simon & Schuster|year=1990|isbn=9780671695385|location=New York|pages=|via=}}</ref>
In 1988, Thomas L. Cooper, one of its former [[Boeing 727]] captain who flew during the [[List of strikes|1989 strike]],<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://file.wikileaks.org/file/airline-pilot-scab-list-2004.pdf|title=This is the US master pilot scablist - The unionist's edition|last=|first=|date=5 June 2004|website=WikiLeaks.org|publisher=WikiLeaks|page=14|access-date=18 July 2016|quote="Cooper, Thomas L, EAL 89, 17392, 10/62, Owner Gulfstream Airlines"}}</ref> launched a small charter company named [[Gulfstream International Airlines]] (GIA) offering flights around South Florida, the Bahamas and Cuba in [[Cessna 402]]s. Early on, Captain candidates paid $15,000 up front starting in 1992 with intermediary business Avtar International doing the recruiting and advertising, selling multi-engine time in [[Cessna 402]]s with the assurance from the Miami Flight Standard District Office that this time was loggable. At the time, captains received compensation only following successful completion of Initial Operating Experience (IOE), First Officers would continue to fly without pay for between 150–200 hours. They were often able to continue flying without purchasing additional hours if replacements didn't come in quickly enough.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.cockpitseeker.com/2014/p1-faa-pilots-p2f/|title=USA: P2F origins (part 1)|last=|first=|date=7 October 2014|website=CockpitSeeker|publisher=|access-date=}}</ref>
== FAA == The [[Colgan Air Flight 3407]] crash led to the [[Federal Aviation Administration]] (FAA) passing new pilot qualification standards.<ref name=bloom /> These standards also addressed a mandate passed by the U.S. Congress when they enacted H.R. 5900 (111th),<ref>{{cite web|title=Press Release – FAA Boosts Aviation Safety with New Pilot Qualification Standards|url=http://www.faa.gov/news/press_releases/news_story.cfm?newsId=14838|website=www.faa.gov/|publisher=Federal Aviation Administration|date=July 10, 2013}}</ref> the Airline Safety and FAA Extension Act of 2010.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.gpo.gov/fdsys/pkg/PLAW-111publ216/pdf/PLAW-111publ216.pdf | title=Airline Safety and FAA Extension Act of 2010 |publisher=U.S. Government |accessdate=December 29, 2014}}</ref>
This act also foresaw the modification of "requirements for the issuance of an airline transport pilot certificate"<ref>{{cite web|title=AIRLINE SAFETY AND FEDERAL AVIATION ADMINISTRATION EXTENSION ACT OF 2010|url=http://www.gpo.gov/fdsys/pkg/PLAW-111publ216/pdf/PLAW-111publ216.pdf|website=www.gpo.gov/|publisher=[US] Government printing Office|pages=21|date=Aug 1, 2010|quote=requirements for the issuance of an airline transport pilot certificate}}</ref> in ways that were implemented by FAA's regulation & policy n°8900.225<ref>{{cite web|title=8900.225 - Pilot Certification and Qualification Requirements for Air Carrier Operations Document Information|url=http://www.faa.gov/regulations_policies/orders_notices/index.cfm/go/document.information/documentid/1021509|website=www.faa.gov/|publisher=FAA|accessdate=19 June 2015}}</ref> titled Pilot Certification and Qualification Requirements for Air Carrier Operations<ref>{{cite web|title=U.S. DEPARTMENT OF TRANSPORTATION FEDERAL AVIATION ADMINISTRATION N 8900.225 National Policy|url=http://www.faa.gov/documentLibrary/media/Notice/N_8900.225.pdf|website=www.faa.gov/|publisher=FAA|accessdate=19 June 2015}}</ref> on July 10, 2013 <ref>{{cite web|title=8900.225 - Pilot Certification and Qualification Requirements for Air Carrier Operations|url=http://www.faa.gov/regulations_policies/orders_notices/index.cfm/go/document.information/documentid/1021509|website=www.faa.gov/|publisher=Federal Aviation Administration|date=July 10, 2013}}</ref>
Aforementioned regulation reduced the scope of 'pay-to-fly' among FAA licensees by raising minimum standards.<ref name=bloom /> Indeed, to serve as SIC (Second In Command or First Officer) :
"A pilot may be eligible if he or she was a military-trained pilot; a graduate of a four-year bachelor degree program with an aviation major; a graduate of a two-year associate degree program with an aviation major; or has 1,500 hours total time as a pilot".<ref>{{cite web|title=Table 5. Receive an ATP Certificate With Restricted Privileges (Restricted to Serving as SIC in Part 121 Operations—Multiengine Class Rating Only)|url=http://www.faa.gov/documentLibrary/media/Notice/N_8900.225.pdf|website=www.faa.gov/|publisher=Federal Aviation Administration|pages=4|format=Table 5. right column. (5)|date=July 10, 2013}}</ref>
No regulations explicitly ban 'pay-to-fly'.
== EASA == [[File:EASA Logo.png|thumb|left|''"The fact that airlines make their personnel pay does not intervene in aviation safety regulation, as long as pilots are technically qualified"''<ref name=france-info /> _Dominique Fouda, Head of [[European Aviation Safety Agency|EASA]]'s Communication Department]] In Europe, among [[European Aviation Safety Agency|EASA]] licence holders, 'pay-to-fly' is a practice acknowledged to exist,<ref name="senat3">{{cite web|url=http://www.senat.fr/rap/r13-450/r13-4501.pdf|title=RAPPORT D´INFORMATION FAIT au nom de la commission des affaires européennes sur le dumping social dans les transports européens|last=|first=|date=April 10, 2014|editor-link=Éric Bocquet|website=Senat.fr|publisher=Sénat (french Senate)|pages=41|language=French|access-date=|quote="La compagnie luxembourgeoise Strategic avait, quant à elle, mis en place un système dit de pay to fly, les jeunes pilotes devant payer pour voler et ainsi acquérir des heures de vol."|last1=BOCQUET|first1=Éric|issue=450}}</ref><ref name="eca2">{{cite web|url=https://www.eurocockpit.be/pages/fair-competition-in-aviation-is-a-must|title=Fair Competition in aviation is a must!|website=www.eurocockpit.be/|publisher=European Cockpit Association|quote=[...] making use of fake work bases in non-European countries, and ‘pay-to-fly’ (P2F) programs (whereby newly graduated pilots have to pay their airline for gaining flying experience on an aircraft)}}</ref> though, "neither the [[European Commission]], nor the [[European Aviation Safety Agency|EASA]] cared":<ref name="france-info2">{{cite news|url=http://www.franceinfo.fr/emission/le-plus-france-info/2013-2014/quand-le-co-pilote-aussi-paie-sa-place-dans-l-avion-06-16-2014-18-30|title=Quand le copilote aussi paie sa place dans l’avion... (When the copilot also pays for his seat in the plane)|date=June 17, 2014|work=France Info (radio)|language=French|author1=Jérôme Jadot}}</ref>
"The fact that airlines make their personnel pay does not intervene in aviation safety regulation, as long as pilots are technically qualified",<ref name="france-info2" /> said Dominique Fouda, [[European Aviation Safety Agency|EASA]] Head of Communication & Quality Department.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://easa.europa.eu/system/files/cv-pdoi/EASA_CV_dfo.pdf|title=Dominique Fouda Professional Profile|website=easa.europa.eu/|publisher=EASA|quote=Head of the Communication department, European Aviation Safety Agency|author1=eschel|accessdate=22 May 2015|archiveurl=http://www.cockpitseeker.com/wp-content/uploads/posts/EASA_CV_dfo.pdf|archivedate=May 22, 2015}}</ref>
[[Pay to fly#Academic research and studies|Several studies]] changed this position however.
===Switzerland=== According to [[Federal Office of Civil Aviation|FOCA]] vice director Marcel Zuckschwerdt:<ref>{{cite web|title=Marcel Zuckschwerdt nouveau sous-directeur à l'OFAC|url=http://www.bazl.admin.ch/aktuell/medieninformation/00024/index.html?lang=fr&msg-id=2217|website=www.bazl.admin.ch/index.html?lang=en|publisher=OFAC/FOCA|language=French|date=November 30, 2000}}</ref>
"There is no regulation that would prohibit from doing this [pay-to-fly], it is absolutely possible. One can wonder of course, is it safe? Is it acceptable in terms of safety? And when we examined the matter, we reached the conclusion that, in the end, it's the pilot motivation that is the argument to say it is satisfying in terms of safety" <ref name="rts" /> (at 9':50")
===France=== 'Pay-to-fly' is illegal per social regulation as a work contract can be established on demand by a judge as long as: # there's a proven subordination relationship between the service provider and the party benefiting from said service; # the moral or physical person benefiting from the service enforces a framework to which the service provider abides. Legal action can be taken in case of violation, and sanctions can amount from 45,000 to 220,000 euros in fines and 3 years of prison.<ref>{{cite web|title=Contrat de travail|url=http://contrat-de-travail.comprendrechoisir.com/comprendre/requalification-contrat-de-travail|website=contrat-de-travail.comprendrechoisir.com/|publisher=ComprendreChoisir|language=French}}</ref> According to the French [[Directorate General for Civil Aviation (France)|DGAC]], "pay-to-fly is not used among carriers operated under the French flag" <ref name="france-info" /> which doesn't prevent French pilots from suffering from it.<ref name="france-info" /><ref name=france-2 /><ref name=slate />
====Statistics==== In 2013, 1,739 French pilots were registed in [[Pôle emploi]], a 43% rise as per the three preceding years.<ref name=france-info /> In December 2014, graduate student pilots from the [[École nationale de l'aviation civile|ENAC]] (French Civil Aviation University) alone, reported under the AGEPAC association that, from 2006 to 2011 concerning a sample of 319 pilots:<ref>{{cite web|title=STATISTIQUES DES ELEVES PILOTES DE LIGNE PROMOTIONS 2006 - 2011|url=http://www.agepac.org/fichiers/files/AGEPAC_Suivi-EPL_Dec2014.pdf|website=www.agepac.org/|publisher=AGEPAC (Association Générale des Elèves Pilotes de l’Aviation Civile)|language=French}}</ref> * 15% were voluntary workers/without activity/registered in [[Pôle emploi]]<ref>{{cite web|title=STATISTIQUES DES ELEVES PILOTES DE LIGNE PROMOTIONS 2006 - 2011|url=http://www.agepac.org/fichiers/files/AGEPAC_Suivi-EPL_Dec2014.pdf#page=6|website=www.agepac.org/|publisher=AGEPAC (Association Générale des Elèves Pilotes de l’Aviation Civile)|page=6|language=French}}</ref> * 42% didn't have an activity allowing them to fly<ref name=frastat>{{cite web|title=STATISTIQUES DES ELEVES PILOTES DE LIGNE PROMOTIONS 2006 - 2011|url=http://www.agepac.org/fichiers/files/AGEPAC_Suivi-EPL_Dec2014.pdf#page=7|website=www.agepac.org/|publisher=AGEPAC (Association Générale des Elèves Pilotes de l’Aviation Civile)|page=7|language=French}}</ref> * 44% deemed their activity wasn't in accordance with their training<ref name=frastat /> * Salaried employment rate (all employment fields) went gradually from 94% for 2006 trainees to 15% for 2011 ones.<ref>{{cite web|title=STATISTIQUES DES ELEVES PILOTES DE LIGNE PROMOTIONS 2006 - 2011|url=http://www.agepac.org/fichiers/files/AGEPAC_Suivi-EPL_Dec2014.pdf#page=8|website=www.agepac.org/|publisher=AGEPAC (Association Générale des Elèves Pilotes de l’Aviation Civile)|page=8|language=French}}</ref> As a result, of the pilots not flying as their main activity: * 86% were willing to move abroad<ref name=frastat1>{{cite web|title=STATISTIQUES DES ELEVES PILOTES DE LIGNE PROMOTIONS 2006 - 2011|url=http://www.agepac.org/fichiers/files/AGEPAC_Suivi-EPL_Dec2014.pdf#page=11|website=www.agepac.org/|publisher=AGEPAC (Association Générale des Elèves Pilotes de l’Aviation Civile)|page=11|language=French}}</ref> * 82% were willing to pay a [[type rating]]<ref name=frastat1 />
===Norway=== The [[Civil Aviation Authority of Norway|Civil Aviation Authority]], responsible for aviation safety in Norway, is not concerned.
According to Frode Lenning, head of Fleet Operation Section, [[Civil Aviation Authority of Norway|CAA]]: “Pilots have been trained within commercial companies for years. However, it is new that some companies ask money to train pilots within their own company [...] We have been training cadet pilots in the cockpit for years, at different levels. What is new here, is the social aspect, and this is not part of the aviation safety regulatory system” <ref name=nrk />".
However, during the pilots' strike of [[Norwegian Air Shuttle|Norwegian]] in March 2015,<ref>{{cite news|title=Norwegian Pilots End Strike After Deal Reached With Airline|url=http://abcnews.go.com/Business/wireStory/norwegian-pilots-end-strike-deal-reached-airline-29534937|publisher=ABC News Internet Ventures|date=March 10, 2015}}</ref> 'pay-to-fly' airline [[Small Planet Airlines]] <ref>{{cite web|title=Small Planet Airline p2f setup with Pilot Management Services (Cyprus)|url=http://www.cockpitseeker.com/wp-content/uploads/goodies/p2f/small-planet-airline/|website=www.smallplanet.aero/|publisher=Small Planet Airlines}}</ref> performed 50 [[Norwegian Air Shuttle|NAS]] slots under [[wet lease]],<ref name=nrk /> establishing a workforce that pay to work while at the same time breaking their colleagues' strike.
===Netherlands=== [[File:Persfoto Wilma Mansveld 03.jpg|thumb|right|''"Given the fact that EASA tackles this issue appropriately and also given the fact that the Dutch aviation sector to the extent known is currently not using these contracts on a large scale, from a safety point of view there is as yet no reason to intervene at a national level."''<ref name=dutch-a/> _[[Wilma Mansveld]]]] Since 2008 the job market for pilots has deteriorated rapidly. Most pilots that have been trained at a Dutch flight school have to look for a job abroad. According to VNV-DALPA the job market for ab initio pilots is poor. "Some companies outside the Netherlands do hire pilots, but these are so-called pay to fly-schemes. This means pilots have to invest a lot of money for a badly paid job and a temporary contract".<ref>{{cite web|title=Werkloosheid in de luchtvaart (Unemployment in aviation)|url=http://www.wordpiloot.nl/voor/page/Grafieken-t-b-v-banenmarkt/Werkloosheid-in-de-luchtvaart/e/ms/34/|website=www.wordpiloot.nl/|publisher=WordPiloot|language=Dutch}}</ref>
On May 22, 2015, Member of [[Dutch Parliament]] [[Martijn van Helvert]] issued a first round of four questions to the House of Representatives of the States General on 'pay to fly', answered on June 2, 2015 by former State Secretary for the Ministry of Infrastructure and the Environment [[Wilma Mansveld]].<ref name=dutch-a>{{cite web|author1=Wilma J. Mansveld|title=Beantwoording Kamervragen van het lid Van Helvert (CDA) inzake zzp piloten (Answers to Parliamentary questions about selfemployed pilots, asked by Member of Parliament Mr Van Helvert (CDA))|url=http://www.rijksoverheid.nl/documenten-en-publicaties/kamerstukken/2015/06/02/beantwoording-kamervragen-van-het-lid-van-helvert-cda-inzake-zzp-piloten.html|website=www.rijksoverheid.nl/|publisher=Rijksoverheid|accessdate=23 July 2015|language=Dutch|date=June 2, 2015}}</ref>
A second round of seven questions and answers followed on June 22, 2015.<ref>{{cite web|author1=Wilma J. Mansveld|title=Beantwoording Kamervragen van het lid Van Helvert (CDA) inzake ZZP-piloten (Answers to Parliamentary questions about selfemployed pilots, asked by Member of Parliament Mr Van Helvert (CDA))|url=http://www.rijksoverheid.nl/documenten-en-publicaties/kamerstukken/2015/06/22/beantwoording-kamervragen-van-het-lid-van-helvert-cda-inzake-zzp-piloten.html|website=www.rijksoverheid.nl/|publisher=Rijksoverheid|accessdate=23 July 2015|language=Dutch|date=June 22, 2015}}</ref>
====Statistics==== In February 2015 the Dutch Airline Pilots Association (VNV - Dutch ALPA) reported 1,200 Dutch pilots out of 4,100 worldwide (almost 30%) were unemployed.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Driessen|first1=Camil|title=Komt Turkish Airlines hier 500 werkloze piloten uit de brand helpen? (Is Turkish Airlines coming to the rescue of 500 unemployed pilots?)|url=http://www.nrcq.nl/2015/02/26/komt-turkish-airlines-hier-500-werkloze-piloten-uit-de-brand-helpen|work=NRCQ|date=February 26, 2015|language=Dutch}}</ref> The unemployment rate remains high.<ref>{{cite web|title=Werkloosheid in de luchtvaart (Unemployment in aviation)|url=http://www.wordpiloot.nl/voor/page/Grafieken-t-b-v-banenmarkt/Werkloosheid-in-de-luchtvaart/e/ms/34/|website=www.wordpiloot.nl/|publisher=Word Piloot|language=Dutch}}</ref>
===Germany=== [[File:2013 01 Jutta Steinruck.jpg|thumb|left|''"Given these strongly undesirable developments in the aviation industry [p2f], I would like to see a determined action by the [[EU Commission]]. An end to the exploitation of young pilots must now be set."''<ref name=js-mep>{{cite web|author1=Jutta Steinruck|title=EU-Kommission macht wenig bis gar nichts gegen ausbeuterische Praktiken von Billig-Airlines (European Commission makes little to nothing against exploitative practices of budget airlines)|url=http://jutta-steinruck.de/2015/07/14/eu-kommission-macht-wenig-bis-gar-nichts-gegen-ausbeuterische-praktiken-von-billig-airlines/|website=jutta-steinruck.de/|publisher=Jutta Steinruck|accessdate=23 July 2015|language=German|date=July 14, 2015|quote=Angesichts dieser krassen Fehlentwicklungen in der Luftfahrtbranche würde ich mir ein entschlossenes Handeln der EU-Kommission wünschen. Der Ausbeutung von jungen PilotInnen muss jetzt ein Ende gesetzt werden.}}</ref> _[[:de:Jutta Steinruck|Jutta Steinruck]]]]On May 5, 2015, Member of [[European Parliament]] [[:de:Jutta Steinruck|Jutta Steinruck]] issued a set of three written questions to the [[European Commission]] under the subject "Exploitative employment models at low-cost airlines (‘Pay to Fly’)":<ref name=mep-q>{{cite web|last1=Steinruck|first1=Jutta|last2=Preuß|first2=Gabriele|last3=Regner|first3=Evelyn|last4=Ertug|first4=Ismail|title=Parliamentary questions|url=http://www.europarl.europa.eu/sides/getDoc.do?pubRef=-//EP//TEXT+WQ+E-2015-007228+0+DOC+XML+V0//EN&language=en|website=www.europarl.europa.eu/portal/en|publisher=European Parliament|accessdate=23 July 2015|date=May 5, 2015|quote=Subject: Exploitative employment models at low-cost airlines (‘Pay to Fly’)}}</ref> # Is the Commission aware that European airlines operate Pay to Fly schemes? <ref name=mep-q /> # Does the Commission agree that this employment model may undermine aviation safety? <ref name=mep-q /> # Does the Commission intend to take action against airlines which operate these exploitative schemes, and will it investigate training systems in the aviation sector? <ref name=mep-q /> On behalf of the [[EU Commission|Commission]], on July 10th 2015, [[Violeta Bulc]] respectively answered:<ref name=mep-a>{{cite web|last1=Bulc|first1=Violeta|title=Parliamentary questions|url=http://www.europarl.europa.eu/sides/getAllAnswers.do?reference=E-2015-007228&language=EN|website=www.europarl.europa.eu|publisher=European Parliament|accessdate=23 July 2015|date=July 10, 2015|quote=Answer given by Ms Bulc on behalf of the Commission}}</ref> # The Commission has been informed recently by pilots' organisations about pay-to-fly schemes used by certain European airlines. The Commission services are currently investigating this specific matter.<ref name=mep-a /> # The Commission has so far not received clear evidence as to the impact of this employment model on safety.<ref name=mep-a /> # Based on the information and data collected, the nature and extent of the phenomenon will be assessed and the need for targeted action discussed at the appropriate level.<ref name=mep-a /> The questions were formulated 2 days before the May 7th 2015 [[European Parliament|EP]] "Committee on Employment and Social Affairs" meeting in Brussels that [[Member of the European Parliament|MEP]] Steinruck also attended where 'pay-to-fly' was discussed.<ref>{{cite web|title=Committee on Employment and Social Affairs - meeting 07/05/2015 15.00-18.30 (video)|url=http://www.europarl.europa.eu/news/en/news-room/content/20150504IPR49627/html/Committee-on-Employment-and-Social-Affairs-meeting-07052015|website=www.europarl.europa.eu|publisher=European Parliament|accessdate=23 July 2015|date=May 7, 2015}}</ref>
====Statistics==== From a 2013 [[Der Spiegel]] article, "According to calculations by [VC spokesman Handwerg]'s union, there are already more than 1,500 unemployed pilots in Germany, an upward trend".<ref name=spiegel>{{cite journal|author1=Deckstein Dinah|title=Prekariat am Himmel (Precarity in the sky)|journal=Der Spiegel|date=March 30, 2013|volume=14|page=61|url=http://www.spiegel.de/spiegel/print/d-91768500.html|language=German|quote=Nach Berechnungen seiner Gewerkschaft gibt es in Deutschland bereits jetzt über 1500 arbeitslose Piloten, Tendenz: steigend.}}</ref>
===United Kingdom=== Following the [[European Cockpit Association|ECA]] Conference of February 12-13th 2015 on "Atypical Employment"<ref name="atypicalEMPL">{{cite web|url=https://www.eurocockpit.be/pages/conference-atypical-forms-of-aircrew-employment-in-the-european-aviation-industry|title=Conference Atypical forms of aircrew employment in the European aviation industry|last=|first=|date=|website=Eurocockpit|publisher=ECA - European Cockpit Association|accessdate=6 November 2015}}</ref> where one "Nextgen pilot [said] pay to fly is wrong but policy makers turning their backs [...]",<ref>{{cite web|title=Nextgen pilot|url=https://twitter.com/BALPApilots/status/566165848608759808|website=twitter.com/BALPApilots|publisher=BALPA|accessdate=6 November 2015|date=February 13, 2015|quote=Nextgen pilot says pay to fly is wrong but policy makers turning their backs. That's the sort of pilot the profession needs #atypicalEMPL}}</ref> [[BALPA]] launched the NexGen program on February 27 to "protect the Profession by reaching down to new entrants".<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.balpa.org/Positions/nextGen|title=nextGen|last=|first=|date=February 27, 2015|website=www.balpa.org|publisher=BALPA - British Airline Pilots Association|quote=BALPA has set up the nextGen programme to help protect the profession by reaching down to these new entrants and giving them a voice.|accessdate=7 November 2016}}</ref> Acknowledging "the most difficult part of pilots’ career is the beginning",<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.balpa.org/Become-A-Pilot/How-To-Become-A-Pilot.aspx|title=How To Become A Pilot|last=|first=|date=|website=www.balpa.org|publisher=BALPA - British Airline Pilots Association|quote=Probably the most difficult part of a pilots’ career is the beginning. Getting that first job can be like finding a needle in a haystack. Most airlines only recruit experienced pilots who have flown jet aircraft before, and are not willing to employ cadets fresh from flight training. This gap is bridged either by paying for extra training, by networking and getting a job flying smaller aircraft or simply by luck.|accessdate=7 November 2015|deadurl=bot: unknown|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160813011229/http://www.balpa.org/Become-A-Pilot/How-To-Become-A-Pilot.aspx|archivedate=13 August 2016|df=}}</ref> Wendy Pursey, head of membership and career services<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.balpa.org/About/team|title=BALPA Staff Listing|last=|first=|date=|website=www.balpa.org|publisher=BALPA - British Airline Pilots Association|quote=Membership & Careers Services - Wendy Pursey Head of Membership and Career Services WendyPursey@balpa.org 0208 476 4088|accessdate=7 November 2016}}</ref> at [[BALPA]] authored<ref name=thegua-p2f>{{cite web|author1=Aida Edemariam|title=Sky high: who'd be an airline pilot today?|url=https://www.theguardian.com/money/2015/oct/24/who-would-be-an-airline-pilot-today|website=www.theguardian.com|publisher=The Guardian|accessdate=8 November 2015|date=October 24, 2015|quote=Wendy Pursey, head of membership and career services at Balpa, wrote a pamphlet, Becoming A Pilot: The Inside Track}}</ref> a booklet titled ''Becoming A Pilot: The Inside Track'',<ref name="balpa-ng-booklet">{{cite web|url=https://www.balpa.org/Members/Career-Services/Become-a-pilot/BALPA-The-Inside-Track.aspx|title=BECOMING A PILOT THE INSIDE TRACK|last=|first=|date=April 23, 2015|website=www.balpa.org|publisher=BALPA - British Airline Pilots Association|pages=16, 23|author1=Wendy Pursey|accessdate=7 November 2016}}</ref> warning : * Some airlines require the pilot to pay for a [[type rating]] in full before commencing training, usually at a cost – about £18,000 to £35,000.<ref name=balpa-ng-booklet /> * It is possible to complete the [[type rating]] and line training without having employment. Some agencies and FTOs will charge you to put you through your [[type rating]] and place you with an airline to operate as a First Officer until completion of your line training. You would receive no salary during hours-building, so arguably you are paying the airline to work for them.<ref name=balpa-ng-booklet /> * The cost of this varies depending upon the company, and often does not usually come with any guaranteed job offer at the end of the line training or hours-building.<ref name=balpa-ng-booklet /> * The risk to consider here is that you are rating yourself on one particular aircraft, and therefore in the event that you do not continue with that airline, it makes you more attractive only to other airlines operating that type, and can be a waste of money if you land a job with the operator of a different type. This airline may then require you to fund another type rating which might be beyond you financially once you’ve funded the first rating.<ref name=balpa-ng-booklet /> "[[BALPA]] does not recommend funding type ratings unless absolutely necessary".<ref name=balpa-ng-booklet />
====Statistics==== Questioned by [[The Guardian]] on October 24, 2015, Pursey assessed : * there are currently 505 unemployed pilots on [[BALPA|Balpa]]’s books.<ref name=thegua-p2f /> * Cadets can graduate with repayment obligations of up to £1,500 a month, no guarantee of a job.<ref name=thegua-p2f /> * Starting salaries as low as £29,000.<ref name=thegua-p2f /> Of the 560 cadets in Balpa’s membership : * for more than 50% of them, the cost of training would exceed £100,000.<ref name=thegua-p2f /> * Only 12% had any kind of sponsorship;<ref name=thegua-p2f /> * 45.2% had taken out a loan,<ref name=thegua-p2f /> * 41.9% were being helped by their parents.<ref name=thegua-p2f />
== Academic research and studies ==
=== French Senate report === On April 10, 2014, Senator [[Éric Bocquet]] released an Information Report on behalf of the European Affairs Commission on social dumping in European transport.<ref name="senat2">{{cite web|url=http://www.senat.fr/rap/r13-450/r13-4501.pdf|title=RAPPORT D´INFORMATION FAIT au nom de la commission des affaires européennes sur le dumping social dans les transports européens|last=|first=|date=April 10, 2014|editor-link=Éric Bocquet|website=Senat.fr|publisher=Sénat (french Senate)|pages=41|language=French|access-date=|quote="La compagnie luxembourgeoise Strategic avait, quant à elle, mis en place un système dit de pay to fly, les jeunes pilotes devant payer pour voler et ainsi acquérir des heures de vol."|last1=BOCQUET|first1=Éric|issue=450}}</ref> In the aviation sector specifically (chapter II), subpart B (frauds), Senator Bocquet acknowledged "[[Strategic Airlines Luxembourg]] had, for all intents and purposes, set up a system of pay-to-fly, young pilots having to pay in order to fly and thus acquire flight hours".<ref name="senat2" />
=== Ghent University study === Co-financed by the [[European Commission]] and carried out across 11 countries by the [[Ghent University]] on behalf of the European [http://ec.europa.eu/social/main.jsp?catId=480&langId=en&intPageId=1829 Sectoral Social Dialogue Committee for Civil Aviation] (notably the [[Association of European Airlines|AEA]], the [[European Cockpit Association|ECA]] and the [[Fédération européenne des travailleurs des transports|ETF]]), the study on "Atypical Employment in Aviation" was presented during the High-Level Atypical Employment conference in Paris on 12 and 13 February 2015.<ref name="atypicalEMPL" />
Accounting for policy options, the study concluded:<blockquote>"A mandatory internship for newly licensed cadets should be considered. Pilots fresh from school are in an extremely weak labour market position often only finding jobs at deplorable conditions or even having to resort to pay-to-fly schemes in order to clock up the flight experience required by airlines offering better conditions. [...] It is our strong opinion that pay-to-fly schemes should be prohibited, not only in the European Union, but globally".<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://biblio.ugent.be/publication/6852830/file/6853379.pdf|title=Atypical Employment in Aviation - Final Report|last=|first=|date=February 2015|website=Universiteit Gent|publisher=UGent|page=296|access-date=11 July 2016|quote="A mandatory internship for newly licensed cadets should be considered. Pilots fresh from school are in an extremely weak labour market position often only finding jobs at deplorable conditions or even having to resort to pay-to-fly schemes in order to clock up the flight experience required by airlines offering better conditions. [...] It is our strong opinion that pay-to-fly schemes should be prohibited, not only in the European Union, but globally"}}</ref></blockquote>
=== Expert consultancy === * The [[European Commission]] (both [[Directorate-General for Mobility and Transport|DG MOVE]] and [[Directorate-General for Employment, Social Affairs and Inclusion|DG EMPL]]) met the [[European Cockpit Association|ECA]] and Cockpitseeker on June 18 to collect their views and evidence.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.cockpitseeker.com/wp-content/uploads/posts/2015-12-09%20Sub-group%20social%20matters%20in%20air%20transport_P2F.pdf|title=5. Other analyses from stakeholders and Member States|last=|first=|date=9 December 2015|work=|publisher=CockpitSeeker|access-date=11 July 2015|via=}}</ref> * Partly in Response to [[Member of the European Parliament|MEP]] [[:de:Jutta Steinruck|Jutta Steinruck]]'s [[#Germany|questions]], [[Steer Davies Gleave]] delivered to [[Directorate-General for Mobility and Transport|DG MOVE]] its study on "employment and working conditions in air transport and airports" on October 2, 2015.<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=http://ec.europa.eu/transport/modes/air/studies/doc/2015-10-employment-and-working-conditions-in-air-transport-and-airports.pdf|title=Study on employment and working conditions in air transport and airports|last=Offord|first=Rosie|last2=Kouris|first2=Stefan|date=2 October 2015|website=ec.europa.eu|publisher=Steer Davies Gleave|pages=21, 159, 163|format=pdf|access-date=11 July 2016|quote="Pay-to-fly schemes are schemes that require pilots to contribute financially to an airline 'in order to be allowed to fly and thus gain requisite flight experience'. Junior pilots without significant amounts of flight (type rating) experience are particularly vulnerable to such practices, although it is not clear how prevalent this is, or precisely which airlines are offering these schemes. [...] Pay-to-fly is acknowledged in published literature (e.g. Atypical employment study, Ghent University) as an issue however stakeholders did not specifically comment in this area."|last3=Capek|first3=Hannah|last4=Wainwright|first4=Stephen|edition=3.0}}</ref> It found that: "Pay-to-fly schemes are schemes that require pilots to contribute financially to an airline 'in order to be allowed to fly and thus gain requisite flight experience'. Junior pilots without significant amounts of flight ([[type rating]]) experience are particularly vulnerable to such practices, although it is not clear how prevalent this is, or precisely which airlines are offering these schemes. [...] Pay-to-fly is acknowledged in published literature (e.g. Atypical employment study, Ghent University) as an issue however stakeholders did not specifically comment in this area."<ref name=":0" />
=== French National Assembly report === On June 28, 2016, deputy member of the Assemblée Nationale [[Gilles Savary]] presented an Information Report<ref name="assembnat">{{cite web|author1=Gilles SAVARY|title=RAPPORT D’INFORMATION DÉPOSÉ PAR LA COMMISSION DES AFFAIRES EUROPÉENNES sur la stratégie européenne pour l’aviation présentée par la Commission européenne le 7 décembre 2015 (COM(2015) 613 final)|url=http://www.assemblee-nationale.fr/14/pdf/europe/rap-info/i3887.pdf|website=assemblee-nationale.fr|publisher=Commission des affaires européennes|accessdate=13 February 2017|page=66|language=French|date=28 June 2016|quote=...la législation sociale dans le secteur aérien n’est pas seulement mal appliquée, elle est aussi insuffisante, les formes de travail atypiques (contrats zéro heures, système « pay-to-fly », faux indépendants et sociétés boîtes aux lettres) ne relevant pas d’une interprétation divergente des règles mais bien des lacunes de ces dernières.}}</ref> on behalf of the commission for European Affairs and focused on the european strategy for aviation issued by the [[European Commission]] on December 7, 2015. Paragraph II.C.1. asserts that Senator [[Éric Bocquet|Bocquet]]'s [[Pay to fly#French Senate report|report]] "published little more than two years ago established an enlighting overview on social dumping associated with applicable right in the air transport, which remains fully relevant to this day".<ref>{{cite web|author1=Gilles SAVARY|title=RAPPORT D’INFORMATION DÉPOSÉ PAR LA COMMISSION DES AFFAIRES EUROPÉENNES sur la stratégie européenne pour l’aviation présentée par la Commission européenne le 7 décembre 2015 (COM(2015) 613 final)|url=http://www.assemblee-nationale.fr/14/pdf/europe/rap-info/i3887.pdf|website=assemblee-nationale.fr|publisher=Commission des affaires européennes|accessdate=13 February 2017|page=65|language=French|date=28 June 2016|quote=.Le rapport d’information de M. Éric Bocquet [...] publié voilà un peu plus de deux ans fait un panorama éclairant du risque de dumping social associé au droit applicable dans le transport aérien, qui reste pleinement d’actualité.}}</ref> Subsequent II.C.1.a. titled "[[European Commission]] adopts a near ''laissez-faire'' attitude towards the labour aspect" states: <blockquote>"Representative stakeholder organizations heard by the rapporteur brought an important nuance [...]: labour law in the [aviation] sector is not only poorly applied but also insufficient. Atypical employment forms (zero hours contracts, «pay-to-fly» scheme, fake self-employment and mailbox companies) aren't to blame on diverging rule interpretation but truly on their loopholes".<ref name="assembnat" /></blockquote>
== Related incidents/accidents == [[File:Airbus A320-214, MyTravel Airways JP6113702.jpg|alt=Airbus A320-214, MyTravel Airways|thumb|[[Airbus A320 family|Airbus A320]]-214, [[MyTravel Airways]]]]
=== MyTravel Airways === On 5 July 2007, a [[First Officer (civil aviation)|First Officer]] who was not an employee but was paying [[MyTravel Airways|MyTravel]] to gain flight experience on their aircraft (pay-to-fly), landed an Airbus A320 heavily at Kos airport in Greece causing substantial damage to the main landing gear.<ref name="AAIB-mytravel" /> The report was critical of both the pilots training record and non-employees paying airlines to gain experience.
In February the same year, MyTravel Group plc agreed on a merger with [[Thomas Cook AG]]<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.ft.com/content/a5c4380a-ba34-11db-89c8-0000779e2340|title=MyTravel agrees merger with Thomas Cook|last=Spikes|first=Sarah|last2=Blitz|first2=Roger|date=February 12, 2007|website=ft.com/|publisher=Financial Times|access-date=December 16, 2016|quote=MyTravel, the £1.1bn UK holiday company, and Thomas Cook, its privately-owned Germany-based rival, on Monday agreed a merger of equals that would create a global powerhouse of tour operators.}}</ref> that became effective in June.<ref name=":1">{{Cite web|url=http://thomascookairlinesuk-newsroom.condor.com/en/int/about-us/history/|title=Thomas Cook Airlines' history|last=|first=|date=|website=thomascookairlinesuk|publisher=Thomas Cook Airlines UK|access-date=December 16, 2016|quote=Following the merger between Thomas Cook AG and MyTravel Group plc in June 2007, the new Thomas Cook Airlines (amalgamating Thomas Cook Airlines UK Ltd and MyTravel Airways) is launched at Gatwick on 30th March 2008.}}</ref> As a result, the accident occurred under the common umbrella of [[Thomas Cook Group|Thomas Cook Group plc]] (as listed on the [[London Stock Exchange]]), with [[MyTravel Airways]] and Thomas Cook Airlines UK Ltd fusing into [[Thomas Cook Airlines]] on 30 March 2008.<ref name=":1" />
==Controversy== {{col-begin}} {{col-break}}
===Pros=== Defending the 'pay-to-fly' model, a Cockpit4u spokeswoman stated: "It opens up career starters opportunities that are currently not offered on the European market. Abroad such training programs have been common for years".<ref>{{cite journal|author1=Deckstein Dinah|title=Prekariat am Himmel (Precarity in the sky)|journal=Der Spiegel|date=March 30, 2013|volume=14|page=61|url=http://www.spiegel.de/spiegel/print/d-91768500.html|language=German|quote=Es eröffne Berufseinsteigern "Chancen, die sich im europäischen Markt derzeit nicht bieten". Derartige Trainingsprogramme seien im Ausland schon seit Jahren üblich.}}</ref>
[[Baltic Aviation Academy]]'s view: When employed regularly, one "will most likely sign an agreement which indicates some sort of liabilities [...] and concessions for the company" that will "commit [oneself] to fly for a few years with that airline" with a "salary deduction from your monthly payment" in order to reimburse the airline's investment on the pilot whereas, one can "choose paid Line Training" to gain "independence" and avoid being "absolutely in [an airline's] service", to "gain the 'luxury' of choosing the airline which you would love to work for and ability to focus on the job which will bring you everyday pleasure" <ref name=baa-st>{{cite web|title=Line Training: to pay or not to pay?|url=http://www.balticaa.com/line-training-to-pay-or-not-to-pay/|website=www.balticaa.com/|publisher=Baltic Aviation Academy|date=February 25, 2015}}</ref>
"Independence" comes at 19,500 euros the [[type rating]], to which a line training opportunity can be added that "can vary from 46,000 to 55,000 euros" <ref name=baa-tr-lt-1 />
[[Avia Solutions Group|AviationCV]] reckons: "Line training price depends on the type of aircraft [...] line training A320 might cost around 40 000 – 50 000€ [...]. Usually cadets are asked to pay around 60% of payment before the program and rest of it after. It is important to mention that when obtaining for line training, pilots are not being paid."<ref name=aviationcv-go-p2f>{{cite web|author1=AviationCV.com|title=Line training for pilot: everything you need to know|url=http://www.aviationcv.com/aviation-blog/2015/line-training-for-pilot-everything-you-need-to-know|website=www.aviationcv.com/|publisher=AviationCV|accessdate=23 July 2015|archiveurl=http://www.cockpitseeker.com/wp-content/uploads/posts/AviationCV_Line-training-for-pilot_everything-you-need-to-know.pdf|archivedate=July 14, 2015|date=July 14, 2015}}</ref> adding: "Despite the opinion that line training destroys the airline pilot industry (“Pay to fly”), line training is in itself necessary [...]. For sure, there was a time when airline pilot training was sponsored by the airline hiring a pilot. However, the situation has changed and only few airlines still apply this policy [...]. In order to start your pilot’s career, you need to invest."<ref name=aviationcv-go-p2f /> {{col-break}}
===Cons=== Since the beginning of the [[Great Recession|recession]] “pay to fly” contracts have been introduced by some carriers. These contracts are designed to provide flexibility to the carrier and usually involve all the training costs being met by the applicant.<ref name=balpa-ng-booklet /> Unfortunately at present, due to the economic situation and the surplus of pilots, this appears to be becoming an increasing trend and arguably results in individuals having limited loyalty and moving on to another airline which offers better careers, contracts/benefits/pay and long-term permanent employment at the earliest opportunity. In order to remain competitive many other carriers are seeing this as an attractive option resulting in potentially this type of contract being more common in the future. According to [[BALPA]], "this is shortsighted and will ultimately deter some potentially good pilots from entering the industry",<ref name=balpa-ng-booklet /> adding the Association is "concerned by the implications long-term".<ref name=balpa-ng-booklet />
The spreading of the practice is also linked to the rise of pilot generations "slowly strangled by their debt"<ref>{{cite web|last1=Groenendijk-Feenstra|first1=Nienke|url=https://werklozevliegers.wordpress.com/2015/02/19/interview-met-airobserver/|publisher=AirObserver|date=October 18, 2013|title=Pilots are slowly strangled by their debt}}</ref> where, pilot unions warn, "only the wealthiest, rather than the best, candidates will become pilots, because growing numbers of airlines are having their cadets pay to fly".<ref>{{cite web|title=Even the pilots pay on some low-cost flights|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/travel/news-and-advice/even-the-pilots-pay-on-some-lowcost-flights-9028635.html|website=www.independent.co.uk|publisher=The Independent|date=December 29, 2013}}</ref>
The [[European Cockpit Association|ECA]] considers pay-to-fly as being "flexible contractual set-ups that are often at the edge of what is legal and what is necessary to guarantee flight safety".<ref name=eca>{{cite web|title=Fair Competition in aviation is a must!|url=https://www.eurocockpit.be/pages/fair-competition-in-aviation-is-a-must|website=www.eurocockpit.be/|publisher=European Cockpit Association|quote=[...] making use of fake work bases in non-European countries, and ‘pay-to-fly’ (P2F) programs (whereby newly graduated pilots have to pay their airline for gaining flying experience on an aircraft)}}</ref>
"These set-ups force employees into temporary contract relationships, fake self-employment (e.g. requiring air crew to set up their own limited liability company that offers its services though agencies to the airline), and/or making use of fake work bases in non-European countries, and ‘pay to fly’ (P2F) programs (whereby newly graduated pilots have to pay their airline for gaining flying experience on an aircraft)" <ref name=eca />
Aside from a French senator report of information in the name of European commission affairs on [[social dumping]] in transports<ref name=senat /> and a European petition supported by the [[European Cockpit Association|ECA]], as far as 'pay-to-fly' is concerned, no regulation and no legislation have been proposed so far. {{col-end}}

{{nofootnotes|date=December 2011}}
'''Process optimization''' is the discipline of adjusting a process so as to optimize some specified set of parameters without violating some constraint. The most common goals are minimizing cost and maximizing throughput and/or efficiency. This is one of the major [[quantitative property|quantitative]] tools in industrial [[decision theory|decision making]].
When [[optimization|optimizing]] a process, the goal is to maximize one or more of the process specifications, while keeping all others within their constraints. This can be done by using a [[process mining]] tool, discovering the critical activities and bottlenecks, and acting only on them.
== Areas == Fundamentally, there are three parameters that can be adjusted to affect optimal performance. They are: * Equipment optimization The first step is to verify that the existing equipment is being used to its fullest advantage by examining operating data to identify equipment bottlenecks.
* Operating procedures Operating procedures may vary widely from person-to-person or from shift-to-shift. Automation of the plant can help significantly. But automation will be of no help if the operators take control and run the plant in manual.
* Control optimization In a typical processing plant, such as a [[chemical plant]] or [[oil refinery]], there are hundreds or even thousands of control loops. Each control loop is responsible for controlling one part of the process, such as maintaining a temperature, level, or flow.
If the [[control loop]] is not properly designed and tuned, the process runs below its optimum. The process will be more expensive to operate, and equipment will wear out prematurely. For each control loop to run optimally, identification of sensor, valve, and tuning problems is important. It has been well documented that over 35% of control loops typically have problems.{{Fact|date=June 2008}}
The process of continuously monitoring and optimizing the entire plant is sometimes called performance supervision.
== See also == * [[Calculation of glass properties]], optimization of several properties * [[Deficit irrigation]] to optimize water productivity * [[Process simulation]] * [[Taguchi methods]]
==External links== * [http://Nutek-us.com/wp-txt.html Reference TEXTBOOKS on Taguchi Methods] * [http://rtime.felk.cvut.cz/scheduling-toolbox TORSCHE Scheduling Toolbox for Matlab] is a freely available toolbox of scheduling and graph algorithms. * [http://www.hillstormer.es HillStormer, a Tool for constrained Optimization by Nelder & Mead in Industry and Research.] [[Category:Business process management]] [[Category:Mathematical optimization in business]]

'''Shameem Ahsan''' is a Bangladeshi Business leader, Venture capital investor & ICT entrepreneur. He is the Chairman of eGeneration Limited and the past President of [[Bangladesh Association of Software and Information Services|Bangladesh Association of Software and Information Services (BASIS)]]. He is the Director of [[Federation of Bangladesh Chambers of Commerce & Industries|Federation of Bangladesh Chambers of Commerce and Industries (FBCCI)]] and state owned [[Agrani Bank Limited]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.digitalworld.org.bd/speakers/profile/11/shameem-ahsan|title=Shameem Ahsan - Speakers - Digital World-2017 #NonStopBangladesh|website=www.digitalworld.org.bd}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thedailystar.net/bytes/why-local-companies-can-and-should-make-the-majority-our-it-sector-1214125|title=Why local companies can and should make up the majority of our IT sector|date=25 April 2016|publisher=}}</ref> As businessman he has played a pivotal role in the implementation of all the major policy changes related to the ICT sector in last one decade.
==Early life and education== Born in Dhaka, Shameem Ahsan graduated from [[University of Central Oklahoma]].
==Career== Shameem Ahsan is a technology entrepreneur and the co-founder of Baagdoom.com (previously Akhoni.com Ltd.), eGeneration Ltd., Benchmark-eGeneration Ltd., and Element 5 Ltd.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/fenox-venture-capital-launches-200-million-fund-for-bangladesh-startups-300000930.html|title=Fenox Venture Capital Launches $200 Million Fund for Bangladesh Startups|first=Fenox Venture|last=Capital|website=www.prnewswire.com}}</ref> Ahsan is a member of the Prime Minister's Digital Bangladesh Task Force, Government of Bangladesh, which is the highest policy-making body to monitor and implement the vision of building Digital Bangladesh. Ahsan, General Partner of FENOX Venture Capital and The Chairman of Venture Capital and Private Equity Association of Bangladesh (VCPEAB).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.clickittefaq.com/fenox-to-facilitate-investment-platform-for-nrb-shameem-ahsan/|title=Fenox to facilitate investment platform for NRB: Shameem Ahsan - Click Ittefaq|website=www.clickittefaq.com}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://thedailynewnation.com/news/137034/chairman-of-venture-capital-and-private-equity-association-of-bangladesh-shameem-ahsan-speaking-at-meet-the-press-on-proposed-budget-2017-2018-at-krishibid-institution-in-the-citys-khamarbari-on-sunday.html|title=Chairman of Venture Capital and Private Equity Association of Bangladesh Shameem Ahsan speaking at 'Meet The Press' on proposed budget 2017-2018 at Krishibid Institution in the city's Khamarbari on Sunday.|first=The New|last=Nation|publisher=}}</ref> He is currently the Chairman of BASIS Presidents' Forum and Chairman of Venture Capital & Private Equity Association of Bangladesh (VCPEAB). He is the founder and President of TiE Dhaka. He is also a Director of [[Rajshahi Kings]], a popular T20 cricket team of [[Bangladesh Premier League]] (BPL), which reached the final of BPL’2016 by participating for the first time. <ref>{{cite web |title=Rajshahi Kings team |url=http://www.espncricinfo.com/ci/content/squad/1125258.html |website=espncricinfo.com |accessdate=3 July 2018}}</ref>
==Personal life== Ahsan is married to Syeda Kamrun Ahmed, a Women Business Leader and CEO of [[Bagdoom.com]]. They have one daughter.
==Awards & honor== * Best Young Entrepreneur of Bangladesh <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.egeneration.com.bd/about-us/about-chairman/|title=eGeneration - About Chairman|website=www.egeneration.com.bd}}</ref> * Top Outstanding Young Person in Bangladesh

{{About|agreements in labour relations law|use in contract law|Side letter (contract law)}} {{Portal|Organized labour}} A '''side letter''' or '''side agreement''' is a [[collective bargaining]] agreement that is not part of the underlying or primary [[collective bargaining agreement]] (CBA) which the parties to the [[contract]] use to reach agreement on issues the CBA does not cover, to clarify issues in the CBA, or to modify the CBA (permanently or temporarily). One may distinguish side letters from "side settlements" or "settlement agreements", which settle a dispute arising from the underlying CBA.<ref name="CooperTire">[http://caselaw.lp.findlaw.com/data2/circs/6th/054641p.pdf ''United Steelworkers of America v. Cooper Tire & Rubber Company],'' [[case citation|474 F.3d 271]] (6th Cir. 2007).</ref> In rare cases, bargaining parties may use a side letter to adjust the focus of the contract if the parties are not yet ready or willing to adapt the contract formally.<ref>Kaboolian, Linda, and Sutherland, Paul. ''Win-Win Labor-Management Collaboration in Education: Breakthrough Practices to Benefit Students, Teachers, and Administrators.'' Bethesda, Maryland: Education Week Press, 2005. {{ISBN|0-9674795-4-1}}.</ref>
Under the law of contracts, a side letter has the same force as the underlying contract.<ref name="CooperTire" /> However, the courts may invalidate side letters in conflict with the main collective bargaining agreement.<ref>"Eighth Circuit Invalidates Side Letter Agreement Conflicting With Collective Bargaining Agreement". ''Benefits & Compensation Legal & Legislative Reporter.'' October 2004; ''Trustees of the Graphic Communication International Union, Local 1B Health and Welfare Fund "A" v. Tension Envelope Corporation,'' [[case citation|374 F.3d 633]] (8th Cir. 2004).</ref> The terms of the CBA govern interpretation of side letters. In the United States, several [[United States courts of appeals|appellate courts]] have held that in disputes where side letters do not contain [[conflict resolution]] procedures, the parties must use the underlying collective bargaining agreement's dispute resolution mechanism (in these cases, [[arbitration]]) to resolve the dispute.<ref name="CooperTire" /><ref>[http://www.ca7.uscourts.gov/tmp/FH0OGU6E.pdf ''United Steelworkers v. Trimas Corporation]{{dead link|date=May 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }},'' No. 07-1688 (7th Cir. July 3, 2008).</ref><ref name="Dube">Dube, Lawrence E. "Court Orders Arbitration on Neutrality Pact, But Says NLRB May Have to Decide Legality". ''Daily Labor Report.'' September 10, 2007.</ref>
The range of issues side letters covers is wide. In some cases, side letters have driven national [[labour law]] policy. For example, in the United States, a side letter guaranteeing employer neutrality during union elections in newly acquired plants, subsidiaries, or divisions led to a federal lawsuit over the legality of the agreement in 2002 and a major decision by the [[National Labor Relations Board]] revising federal labour policy in 2007.<ref name="Dube" /><ref>''Int'l Union v. Dana Corp.,'' [[case citation|278 F.3d 548]] (6th Cir. 2002); Gross, Jared S. "Recent Developments: International Union v. Dana Corp." ''Ohio State Journal on Dispute Resolution.'' 2003; Moody, Kim. [http://www.labornotes.org/node/1485 "'Card Check' Takes a Hit"]. ''Labor Notes.'' January 2008; Barker, Joseph A. "Keeping Neutrality Agreements Neutral". ''Michigan Bar Journal.'' August 2005; McGolrick, Susan J. "Attorneys for Dana Corp., Unions Criticize NLRB Decision on Voluntary Recognition". ''Human Resources Report.'' March 3, 2008; "NLRB 3-2 Modifies Recognition Bar". ''U.S. Law Week.'' October 9, 2007.</ref>
In [[Australia]], side letters are becoming increasingly common due to the changes in federal labour law the [[WorkChoices]] Act created. WorkChoices limits the collective bargaining agreements that parties can register for eligibility for workplace tribunals enforcement, and also requires CBAs be strictly limited to work-related issues. The inclusion of even minor non-workplace-related clauses (such as dues check-off) can render a CBA unenforceable. In response, many unions and employers are using side letters to reach agreement on non-workplace-related matters, and not registering these side-letters with the federal government—relying on [[common law]] to enforce the side letters.<ref>Stewart, Andrew and Riley, Joellen. "Working Around WorkChoices: Collective Bargaining and the Common Law". ''Melbourne University Law Review.'' 2007.</ref>
